title: Has anyone ever given someone a job because they sent a thank you email after an interview? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not exactly my situation, but close. When I was still in a bank management career, I became a reserve deputy sheriff with the Orange County (CA) Sheriff’s Department (I was bored after a divorce so I joined up to fill some time). After 3 years of being a reserve deputy (serving in patrol, investigations, and firearm instructor), I saw a private investigation and security consulting firm that had a branch in Irvine, CA profiled in the Orange County Register newspaper. It was founded and run by former folks who worked at places like LAPD, LA Sheriff’s Office, Secret Service, FBI, CIA, and other federal/municipal agencies. I thought it sounded like a very cool place to work, so I looked them up, wrote them a letter saying who I was and what I could do for them. No word for 2 weeks after I sent the letter, so I called to follow up. I spoke to a guy who introduced himself as the Operations Officer (also former LAPD) and he said he recalled getting the letter, but they had no openings. He said they would keep my letter in their files though (yeah right, I thought to myself) because they might be able to use me on some close protection details on a case-by-case basis because I could carry a firearm. I never expected to hear from them…but, lo and behold, 2 weeks later the Operations Officer called. He said they were going to be expanding their investigations side of the business and would I like to join them as a trainee. I said not only yes, but hell yes. I was assigned to a former FBI agent who was working BRI as a retirement job and learned a ton from him. I had to take a cut in pay to start but in the long run the position led to a long career in the corporate and government security world which I am still enjoying.

Sure! Sending a thank you email to your prospective employer after you’ve completed the interview can be a great way to follow up with them and keep yourself “top of mind”. In the hiring that I’ve done, VERY FEW job candidates actually ever reach out after the interview to follow up. Basically, they come in at their scheduled time, do the interview, then disappear - waiting for you to follow up with them later. The problem is, as a hiring manager, after doing several interviews you’re left with a stack of resumes & notes, and limited time to try and remember everything based on the interviews you’ve done. It can be a rather impersonal process. So having a thank-you followup from a candidate is a great way to make that process a little more personal, and in my opinion it will tend to give their resume a bit more weight, because it puts them back in your radar. Additionally, a thank you letter demonstrates that the candidate actually is interested in the job. Sometimes it’s hard to gauge genuine enthusiasm for the position from the interview, because all the candidates to their best to demonstrate it. So the thank you letter is “above and beyond” demonstrating that the candidate truly is interested in the job. Finally, I’d say that a thank you letter helps to demonstrate that self-motivated “go-getter” attitude that you really want to look for in a candidate. It means that they’re not only interested, they’re motivated. That’s big. I’ve written many thank you letters myself, and typically I try to start the letter out with a sentence describing what went right in the interview (obviously don’t mention things that don’t go smoothly). Then, I try to touch on some of the key points discussed in the interview, and offer short reminders of why my skills are a good fit for those requirements. Then finish it up with a “looking forward to contributing to your team” line, and of course your contact info at the bottom. Voila! The “thank you” part is more important than the summary in my opinion - keep it short, don’t write a book. But it is nice to remind them of why you’re a great candidate. Hey - you’re not done yet! Set yourself a reminder to follow up with them in a week, 2 weeks, and then after that, if they still haven’t made a decision, space the followups out a little further apart so you don’t come across as desperate. Sometimes the employer will tell YOU how long the interview & hiring review process will take. If they say “we won’t be finished for 2 weeks”, then don’t follow up with them in a week and expect things to be finished. Although it may be worth following a little early if you’re super eager about the job - I’ve done this a few times in the past. Usually they don’t get upset, and it still demonstrates real interest. Job interview followup is all about balance: do enough so that they know you’re there and you’re ready & interested - don’t overdo things so that it drives them nuts. Demonstrate that you’re ready & eager, not that you’re stalking them.

Yes - however this was a thank you email not just after the interview, but after a REJECTION email. I applied for a software engineering job at a startup company. They were a 4 person team at the time and were in need of another engineer to help them out. I applied thinking the opportunity sounded awesome and was surprised to get an invitation to interview over the phone with them. I spoke to the CTO and the other lone engineer, and the next day I received a rejection email stating they liked me but were concerned with the lack of experience in the stack they were using (primarily Rails). I totally understood where they were coming from. A 4 person team still in the very early stages of building this company. Of course it’d be a bit nerve-wracking to bring in a candidate that they’d just have to take a leap of faith that I could come onboard, learn, and without taking up too much of anyone else’s time become a very productive member of the team relatively fast. So, I responded and told them, sincerely, thanks for their time and how I totally understood their position. That if I were in their shoes I’d be worried of the same thing. But I then stated - that I even though I understood, I KNOW I could come on board and be an effective hire for them. I didn’t hear anything back from them until a few days later when they said they’d like to meet one more time. There was nothing in the email that suggested it was an additional interview, but rather a quick “hey, let’s meet” email, so I took it as a networking opportunity and went with it. Turned out, after we chatted for a bit, they said “we’d like to bring you onboard”. That was a major turning point in my career to be honest. Later, I found out that my thank you email convinced them to reconsider and give me a shot.

Here are two notes: Dear Sir, Thank you for interviewing me. I think your company is great. Sincerely, Me And Dear Sue, Thank you for taking time out of your schedule to meet with me. The work you are doing on intuitive email interfaces is really intriguing, as it aligns with my research. I enjoyed the interview and think I could contribute significantly with my social clustering work, which I think could complement your current graph-based approach to increase flexibility in group selection. Please don’t hesitate to contact me if I can offer more information Sincerely, Me Now, this is exaggerated, but the second note shows a few critical things. First, I took away something from the interview, and understand what the company is working on. Second, I have unique qualifications that would make this work better. Yes, this example was highly specific, but the work and skills can be more general. Some responses state, “No, if you are not a fit…” What that means is this: if the company doesn’t want to hire you, they won’t hire you. I think you could figure that out. However, a thank you note can make a difference if you are in the running, but there are multiple candidates. You almost never learn why you were or were not hired. A thank you note could make the difference in the right situation; some people might not be willing to hire a candidate who doesn’t send them, or in a situation where a group of people are responsible for hiring, a personal thank you note to one of them might touch the right note so that they advocate for you. Also, long-term effects, which often tend to be network effects in every sense of the word, are important. You’ve left another, almost assuredly positive impression on someone. They may need someone later or know people who need someone. You don’t know and won’t know and can’t know, but as a job candidate, you are trying to feed grist into the mill until you get the right offer. If you think, “The likelihood is low”, you’ll never do what you need to do to get a job. I’ve seen this time and again. I’ve seen people not apply to jobs because either they or the job aren’t a perfect fit, as though you could know that from an ad. tl;dr While a thank-you note will not get you every job, or get you a job where the hiring manager, etc., didn’t want to hire you, it can help in some circumstances, and you’ll never know when it’s important, so just do it.

In one job I got, a member of the hiring committee told me repeatedly that I was the only applicant to follow up with a thank you note after the day of interviews. I had sent a note to each person who took the time to talk to me, thanked them for their time, and mentioned something that I found interesting or helpful during the one-on-one interview with them. The whole process probably took under an hour. I don’t think that secured the job, but it clearly mattered very much to at least one person on the committee, who evidently became a strong advocate for me. I also expect it made a good impression on the others. When I’ve interviewed people, I have found such notes a pleasure to receive — especially if the person took the trouble to personalize the message. I didn’t send the thank you notes out of any expectation it would secure the job. I did it partly out of my notion of decorum, partly out of genuine gratitude, and partly out of genuine interest in what the various interviewers had to say. Having been on the other side, I understand that interviewing job candidates for faculty positions is a disruptive, time consuming, and necessary activity. It’s worth a little time to make the process collegial and pleasant. It’s also helpful to me to focus on what was interesting to me about the interviews — I want to work at a place where there is interesting stuff happening! As a final note, keeping things friendly and collegial not only makes the process more pleasant for everyone, it could pay off later. The person you thank may think of you later when a new position comes up or when someone else asks them for referrals. You may run into them later in a professional context. Burning bridges is bad for you, building bridges is good for everyone.

Great question. Here is my personal adventure. I left Stryker in April 2017 after my role was eliminated (As was pretty much anyone with International Marketing in their title across the company). I started the job hunt and it was a roller coaster of ups and downs. I interviewed with 10 companies and 4 of them twice. Twice as in for different roles. I maintained a positive attitude with everyone I interacted with. I communicated with the hiring manager and recruiter positively with “thank you” in every email. The recruiters remembered me, both from a good candidate perspective and that I followed up with them. I was also able to refer a former colleague to one of the companies via the recruiter. It was pretty satisfying to get a quick response from the recruiter thanking me for the recommendation and that she was setting up the call with my former colleague that week. After almost a year I landed at Mitek Sports Medicine with JnJ. I am not sure I got the job based on a “thank you”, but I most certainly sent them. This past year has been both a challenge and rewarding from all the networking I have done, the people I have met, and my growth along the way. Not to mention the industry insights I have gained with the companies I interviewed with. Good luck. And yes, send those thank you notes! Jules

How about college? The work expended at one is often as much or more difficult than a job. My son got accepted at MIT after being wait-listed as a result of a “Thank You” letter. When my son applied to MIT, he received an email from them, informing him that, although he was not accepted, that his application would be wait-listed pending any possible openings. Of course, this form letter was sent to over 100 students. As very few admission offers from MIT are not accepted, his chances were not great. I told him to send the admissions office an email thanking them for considering him. As MIT was his first choice, I also told him to offer his guarantee that he would attend MIT if he was removed from the wait-list and formally accepted. He did so, responding with an eloquent and well-crafted e-mail that was written according to proper grammatical form and standards. Four weeks later, he called to me to “…come here for a minute.” As I am a paraplegic confined to a wheelchair, I asked him if he could bring it to me. He responded that he had received an email that he thought was a prank and I had to see it. I got into my chair and rolled into the room where he was seated at his computer. The email began, “We are pleased to announce that you have been removed from our wait-list and are accepted into MIT for the year….”

Writing a thank you note to the hiring manager within 24 hours after interviewing is more than a standard practice – it’s a move that demonstrates your commitment to the hiring process, conveys your interest in the position, and ensures you stay fresh on the interviewer’s mind after the initial meeting. If you are determined to be chosen for the job, a good thank you note can make all the difference. To help you effectively communicate your gratitude for being considered, and reiterate how well-suited you are for the role, we’ve answered four of the most frequently asked questions about thank you notes, here: 1. Do hiring managers even read thank you notes? Some don’t, but there are many that do. In fact, most hiring managers expect a follow-up note regardless of whether they intend on reading it or not because they consider them to be a sign of respect. Additionally, the act of sending a thank you note is indicative of the professionalism and consideration you possess, and taking the time and effort to do so communicates that you are a candidate with serious interest in the position. In general, send one – it can’t hurt. 2. What should I include in my thank you note? A well-written thank you note touches upon a variety of topics that work together to wrap up your interviewing experience in a concise message that: Expresses your appreciation for the opportunity to interview with the hiring manager;Reiterates your interest in the position and in the organization;Concisely recaps the qualities and value you can bring to the role;Requests information about the next steps in the process.Remember, a thank you note also serves as a testament to your writing skills and attention to detail, so make sure your note is articulate and free of errors. 3. Is it better to send me letter via email, or snail mail? Though snail mail may appeal to the traditional hiring manager, receiving thank you notes by email is preferred by most hiring managers. Additionally, email expedites the delivery process and offers the candidate the opportunity to immediately emphasize their candidacy for the position while still remaining fresh in the interviewer’s mind. Since many organizations are making their hiring decisions quickly in this day and age, if you choose to send a note through the mail rather than in an email, you run the risk of missing out on the opportunity if they receive the letter after they make their final decision. 4. I interviewed with more than one person – do I need to write each one a thank you note? It’s considered good etiquette to send each person who assists you in your job search a personal thank-you letter, including networking contacts and recruiters. If you met with or were interviewed by several people, reference a specific highlight from each conversation in order to personalize the note.

Not exactly got a job because of the thank you note, but got a second interview which then led to a job. Let me give you some background, I had just finished a masters degree in mechanical engineering and was applying a number of different jobs. One of the positions as a refrigeration design engineer lined up with my profile because I had the work lined up with my experience (I had gotten some after undergrad before going back to school for masters) and my concentration in grad school. The interview was going well, but as it happens sometimes the job description had not been updated for a while. The systems which were mentioned in the description and I was very confident I could design well was not what they were looking for. The company was transitioning to a more environmentally friendly technology, one I at the time of the interview did not even know existed. So of course when they started asking questions about it I was speechless is an understatement. The interview ended shortly after. As the interview ended I knew I had lost the job. I still decided to spend a few hours researching the technology they were planning on adopting. I then crafted a thank you note in which I added the fact that I was aware that I had not been prepared to answer their question during the interview but I have researched and here are the technical challenges company must be facing and what my strategy would be to solve them. They were impressed! I was called back for a second interview and I got the job. The story was told over and over during my employment with them by the hiring team how I had been able to convert a hard no to maybe and then yes by being persistent and showing initiative. I have moved on from that company, but I still stay in touch with the VP of engineering from there and the thank you shows up in conversation every now and then!

Well, I suppose it *might* make the difference if there were two candidates who were otherwise equal in the impression they made…but it’s not going to totally swing the deal if not. I’m in the software business - and I’ve done a lot of interviewing and candidate selection. In my line of work, the engineers on the team do the interviews either individually or in small groups, then we get together afterwards in a meeting room and kick around what we found and either recommend or not the candidate. The team leader picks the winner based on the reactions of the team at those post-interview meetings. If there are thank-you letters, they are probably read and then either filed or tossed away by the HR department - who do not make the final choice between candidates. I can honestly say, as an engineer or as a team leader in half a dozen companies - I’ve never read a thank-you letter. I know people send them - so it can only be that the HR folks don’t think they matter enough to pass them on to the decision-maker. Of course, this is only in my line of work - things might be very different in “service” jobs where inter-personal skills, politeness and other “soft-skills” matter more than technical ability. That said - it certainly can’t hurt to send one. But please, don’t use this as a platform to make excuses for your performance in the interview or say anything that sounds “whiney”…a simple and honest “Thank you” is all you need.

The simple answer to your question is definitely yes. But then the question could be does it help ones case to send a thank you note after an interview? My take is that if the interview was good then the note may assist your case to stay top of mind against other good candidates. If the interview was bad however, the note will not do anything for you. I have received these notes and in my case they didn't add any value beyond what was already discussed during the meeting. It would just be a sheer coincidence in cases where someone who got the job was the one who sent a thank you note. I am a lot more interested in people who interview me during their interview. It makes me feel they take keen interest in assessing who they might be joining. So before you send a thank you note, think about how the interview went. If you feel it wasn't great then just wait for the process to close with the right person recruited. After that you can send a thank you note and request them to keep you in consideration for something more fitting in future. That is if you'd really like to join the company

Yes. I once came into work at my job as a senior software engineer after having worked there less than a month to find out the company (a startup) ran out of funding and they were laying off all of engineering, aside from the CTO. I wrote a thank you letter to the CEO and CTO following this expressing empathy about how hard it must have been to have to lay off 5 people and saying that I’d love to come back and help if conditions improved. Less than two weeks later, they were able to secure an emergency round of funding, after which the CTO was given permission to hire one person to help him. They chose me and having gone back to work there and by the end of the year, I was promoted to head of the department. The company was acquired and I run a department now in a larger organization with secure runway. Always keep connections open, be empathic and stay positive.

I'm not sure it was a thank you note as much as a follow-up. I'll be starting a new position in a couple of weeks. When I first had my interview (by phone) with the hiring manager he asked a lot of questions about willingness and ability to write procedures and document work. He seemed to think his senior level guys weren't doing that very well and were resistant to doing so. I couldn't share with him any procedures I'd written for past employers as it's going to be proprietary and have confidential information like user-id/passwords and IP addresses. But during my career I have written articles for trade journals and white papers when I worked for a hardware vendor that are available to the public and sent him copies of several. I have friends who work in that group. One told me the manager thought I was not strong enough technically but he really didn't ask technical questions. My sending those articles didn't necessarily change his mind but he sent them his entire team and most of the team members said it was clear I know what I'm doing, even if some of that was dated. But I think that even a simple email with "Thank you for the opportunity to discuss the position (name the position). I remain interested in it" is a good idea. But only once.

Maybe… During my final months of my master’s i was applying for job and i was reading blogs about how to face interviews and other tips online. One such tip was to send a Thank you email to the person who interviewed you. I attended only two interviews and I sent them an email thanking them for considering me for the position, spending their valuable time with me and giving a tour of the lab (in one case). I got the job offer from both the companies. I never asked the reason why the hired me among the other handful they interviewed. I believe the thank you email might have played a little in the finalizing process. If a simple thank you email can land you a great job, why not do it ;)

No. What a thank you note gets you is a contact back, even should they decide against you, and they go with another candidate. You are much more likely to hear from them, even with a rejection, with a thank you note out there than without. It also tags you in their mind, should you reapply for a job in the future, when you’ve accumulated more experience, and are then qualified for the job, even if you are not qualified now. I personally like to send paper notes, rather than email. An email is free, it takes almost zero effort on your part, and it most likely lands in their SPAM folder. At best it indicates that you still have an interest in the position following the interview, and you haven’t just moved on to the next company you have on your interview schedule. At worst, your email has just added to their SPAM. A paper note sits on their desk for a while. It stares at them. Unlike an email, it took you some actual effort, and so they are reluctant to just throw it away, at least initially. If you wonder why you never get contacted back when you are not getting hired, it’s probably the lack of a thank you note.

Yes. After an on-site interview, the recruiter contacted me over e-mail of the rejection (for a fresh grad software engineering position). I replied with a brief e-mail noting that I would have loved to work at the company because of the interesting work, career growth and the value of their products. At the end I politely thanked them for the opportunity, which was the main focus. A week later the recruiter called me back with an offer. Most big companies have a systematic hiring process: a no is a no and it’s final. But always keep things positive while doing the best you can for the situation with zero expectation. Do work with, and recognize, people who have the power to influence things within the organization. The reality is there is always an element of unknown.

It can happen. One (fairly common scenario I’ve seen) is where an employer is in no rush to hire and they want to make sure they’re hiring a good individual - so they take their time interviewing. This results in the interviewing period going on for months, with interviewees taking offers from other companies simply because they came to them with an offer first. In those scenarios, I have seen cases where a good interview with a good candidate (good enough to be considered further, but not great enough to give an offer immediately) ends up receiving an offer because they email and indicate that they are within a tight deadline and will need an offer within a certain timeframe (or they will go with another company). Since the company doesn’t want to potentially lose a good candidate, they get an offer out to them. In the scenarios I’ve seen, it has turned out well.

I have interviewed hundreds of teachers and other non-teaching staff in schools. That wouldn't work for us as we make our decision on the day of the interviews. Once we have seen all the candidates who have made it past the lesson teaching stage (some get sent home after they have taught a lesson because they are just not good enough), we discuss the candidates and check their references, then agree on our appointment. Once the agreement is reached, the successful candidate is telephoned with the good news and the unsuccessful candidates are informed, with feedback on why they were unsuccessful. In these circumstances a thank you note, whilst very much appreciated, could not make a difference. I can however, see circumstances where this could work well. My husband has spent many years working as a contractor, taking on roles for varying periods of time. This entails frequent interviews and I would say that even if a person in his position wasn't right for a particular role, the organisation doing the interview would remember someone with enough class to send a note of thanks for the opportunity and it would strike a chord if a more suitable role was to come up.

How about college? The work expended at one is often as much or more difficult than a job. My son got accepted at MIT after being wait-listed as a result of a “Thank You” letter. When my son applied to MIT, he received an email from them, informing him that, although he was not accepted, that his application would be wait-listed pending any possible openings. Of course, this form letter was sent to over 100 students. As very few admission offers from MIT are not accepted, his chances were not great. I informed him to send the admissions company a message thanking all of them for thinking about him. As MIT was their first choice, I also told him to provide his guarantee he would attend MIT if he had been taken from the wait-list and formally accepted. He performed therefore, responding with an eloquent and well-crafted email that was written relating to proper grammatical type and criteria. Four weeks later on, he called if you ask me to “…come right here for a minute.” As I was a paraplegic confined to a wheelchair, I asked him if he could take it to me. He reacted he had gotten a contact which he believed ended up being a prank and I also needed to view it. I obtained into my seat and rolled into the space in which he was seated at their computer system. The email began, “We are happy to announce that you were removed from our wait-list and are usually accepted into MIT for year….”

I got my first job out of college because of thank you letters (not emails). A friend of mine got me and a guy from my graduating class an interview at her company. It was an all day interview. Multiple people were involved, including managers and the lead software engineers. Our friend said we both did really well in the interview but my thank you letters arrived the morning before their meeting to decide between us. The letters were hand written and personalized to each person's interview questions. T For example, the lead was engineer had given me a written test with several questions I did not know the answers to. I looked them up afterward. Always thank the interviewer personally. Let them know you were paying attention. Let them know you're willing to grow and learn. If possible, write the letters by hand because it's more personal. Worst case scenario is you're out a few stamps. Best case is that you get a job you might not have.

Yes, probably, but it’s hard to know. The guys who said ‘No’, for instance, they don’t know. For the office trying to hire a competent person, the interview process is an endless slog. Mostly the candidates suck, and you wonder why you had them in for an interview. Your team each wasted an hour interviewing each one, and they could really have used that time to meet their sprint commitment. There are a couple of candidates that might be OK, but this one has iffy experience, and that one was kinda strange to talk to. Then you get a thank you note. On paper. So you walk it around and say, “Look what came in the mail. Isn’t that nice?” And you talk again about the couple of OK candidates. And guess who’s name you just read, who made you feel good, even for just a moment. Now if you were one of the candidates who sucked, a nice thank you note is not going to get you hired (but it might get you a callback and some super-useful feedback on why you lost out). But if you’re one of the “kinda OK” candidates? Gold, baby.

I hadn’t interviewed with anyone, but I was given a rejection letter to a resume I sent in. I was quite disappointed as I had researched the company and I really liked what they stood for so I decided to write in a thank you letter just for taking the time to send me a rejection as many companies would “ghost” applicants that they deemed were not suitable. In my letter, I also expressed that I would love it if they were to be “frank” with me to let me know why I wasn’t acceptable so that I would be able to improve on myself for future positions. I’m not really sure what I said that changed their mind, but the owner personally contacted me because my response was the exact kind of thinking that they were looking for and decided to give me an interview after all. Long story short, I crushed the interview and I’m still working there after 13 years. It never hurts to be thankful regardless of the situation, and you might get them at just the right time.Also, be sincere. I wasn’t expecting them to suddenly change their minds. It wasn’t a tactic. I was being honest. I truly wanted to be a better person and candidate.

If you blew the interview, that thank you note will not get you the job. Even if it came with a gift basket. I once had a recruiter send me a job posting. She didn't realize her boss’s notes were still in the attachment- her boss said, don't read any resumes with cover letters, they're a waste of time. What also stood out was that her notes said not to hire anyone who sent in a thank you email as they're probably too desperate. Who knew politeness is viewed as weakness that will get you nowhere. Not what my momma taught me.

Yes. I interviewed for a night audit position at a nicer hotel in Milwaukee. During the interview, the manager stressed the importance of thoroughness and details. I was 1 of 5 people who interviewed for the job. I was told by the manager I was one of the top 3 he was considering. When I got home, I sent a nice emailed thank you letter. I reiterated some of the points we discussed and thanked him for his time and the chance to interview at a classic building. I also thanked him for the tour of this building. Less than 12 hrs later, he emailed me back an offer to come work for him. When I asked what decided it for him, he said the over the top decider was the thank you letter. I was the only one who sent one. So now I will take the time to get a direct email address for my interviewer and send that person a short but poignant thank you.

My wife asks for, and receives, business cards of everyone she met at interviews. For her latest position, she was interviewed by 8 people, with one interview being with 6 people. The next morning, all of them found her email waiting for them. Several days later, she was asked to file an official application. A few days later, she was told the job was hers pending a successful background and security check. She didn't get other positions she applied for during the two months she was out of work. Whether the thank you emails helped, who knows. What it does do is to place your name into their memory one more time. Being the last person interviewed also helps. People tend to have short memories of people they will probably never see again. She was the last person interviewed. Did either really help, who knows. What I do know: 1) It doesn't take much effort, 2) It can't hurt. Good luck.

I CAN NOT STRESS THE INPORTANCE of a thank you letter enough. I write individual thank you notes to every person I meet with at an interview. Even when I haven't gotten the job I've REPEATEDLY been told that my personalized notes were appreciated and have even been told I was the only person to write one. Those things show your character and dedication and if people are on the fence between you and someone else it WILL get you the job. Bottom line is-there's no excuse not to give the interview process 100%. I say process because there's so much more to this than just showing up and telling people about yourself. Your pre-interview attitude, questions, and research will come through in the interview and the thank you letters will put you that much farther ahead of the pack. If you want the job then work for it. If you can't work for the interview then it's a sign you won't work for the job when you're in it so anything less than you're best means you don't deserve the job in the first place. Sorry for the tough love but that's the real world. Always be willing to work for the things you want.

Yes. It happened to my son and to me. My son is now in a position to hire, and he’s amazed at how many candidates have failed to follow up with a thank you. I used to tell my kids to do written thank-you notes, but paper and mail take too long. Email works! I got a job several months after an interview thanks to the paper thank-you letter I sent (during the early-Internet days). The guy kept my letter and looked me up when he had a need for my skills. Another time, I had a recruiter call me and tell me to send a thank-you note because the head interviewer really liked me. I got an offer as soon as he received my note.

Not in any company or institute I have worked for, or known about. A practical reason to exclude that is that interviewers usually write their recommendations the same day, typically just after the interview, way before candidates have time to go home and send thank you notes. Candidate evaluation is, unfortunately influenced by randomness, but processes (if done right) are designed to filter out as much as possible. It would be quite a broken candidate evaluation system, if you could sway it with a mere thank you note. There is probably correlation between a candidate sending thank you notes and the candidate receiving an offer (maybe somebody who sends notes is overall a more agreeable person and a good personality match in a broader set of environments), but that’s an indicator, not a cause.

I don't think that “thank-you email” is the main reason to hire someone. But! Follow-up emails after any business meeting are important and will let you be highlighted. Now in 2018 and 2019, there is no B2B or B2C anymore, Today is the era of H2H (human to human) You don't talk to brands, you talk to a real person, you don't pay money to a company. You pay to people you trust. So I highly recommend you send a follow-up email after meetings (no matter what it was, a call via Hangouts or a face-to-face meeting in office). And you’ll succeed. Why? Because 30% of salespeople send 0 follow-up emails after the meetings    & 44% of salespeople give up after the first follow-up  So by sending a second email, you’re above the majority of your competitors. And we've  prepared: 7 rules to write a follow-up email after the business meeting Hope it'll help! Max

Most definitely, my dad was a CFO and taught me to always send a thank you email after an interview. He said that some interviewers won’t even consider an applicant if they do not do so. Thank you letters allow us to do more than just thank the individual for their time. We are able to elaborate on what excites us about the position and point out how well equipped we are to meet those needs. Once we’ve sent a email of appreciation, we are now able to email once again. We can ask if any decision has been made regarding the position without appearing rude.

Yes, on two occasions. I have narrowed my candidate list to a choice few. A follow up email made a difference in whom I hired. One was from a candidate that was not initially in my final selection. They used the follow up to express things they forgot to tell me during the interview and how they felt it related to the position. The other was just a short thank you for the opportunity. But between the candidates this made a difference. Especially when I had not given them my direct contact. Later I found out they had stopped on the way out to get it from my secretary. There is never a wrong time to make a good impression.

A lot of things can happen in the interview process that are behind the scenes and no one really knows what they are except the recruiter and the hiring manager. In the event that another candidate has rejected the offer, you may be called back after a rejection letter is sent if you have sent a lovely thank you note indicating your continued interested in the role. Candidates frequently mention being frustrated that they are not contacted after applying or being interviewed, but often many candidates are ‘final candidates’ and if that ‘first choice’ bails, sometimes you are the runner up. Always send a Thank you note as to most all managers, this shows your enthusiasm in the position and that you hope to remain in the company’s good graces. Cheers!

I used to send a thank-you card, as in a physical card, after interviews. This included interviews where I was still interested in the job and ones where I was not interested in the job after learning more. It just seemed like proper etiquette to send a thank-you and I thought it might help. It did not make a difference. All the jobs I got would have hired me anyway, and it of course did not help me get the jobs I did not end up getting. More recently, I no longer do this. I was experimenting with just a simple follow-up email the next week, of course saying thank you as part of that note. I wonder sometimes if I should have gone back to the old thank-you cards, but then I remember it never helped in the past.

No. Because if I hadn't had all the qualifications, a simple “"thank you” email would not have mattered. However, the email I sent after the first interview was so surprising and so appreciated that it put me into an entirely different class in the mind if the hiring manager. So much of the job seeking business is a numbers game and anything that gives you a positive edge over the competing resumes is an advantage. Being one of the the few, if not the only one, to send a “thank you for taking the time to interview me”, gave me just the edge I needed to get the offer. Of course, once a bunch of other applicants figure this out, then the thank you email will no longer be special and won't give you any advantage. It will, however, become required and those that don't, will be immediately removed from consideration. Ain't job hunting fun?

I would never base a hiring decision on that. I hate that “thank you notes” are a thing in general; this is a discussion on business between two people trying to determine a mutual fit. My time is not more valuable than theirs, I don’t need to be thanked for it. It’s not a downside, certainly, it’s a nice and polite thing to do, but I have a hard time imagining a good reason for it to even contribute to a hiring decision. I don’t like making candidates jump through hoops or encouraging a system where candidates must do things like send thank-you notes that aren’t necessarily intuitive and just create another level of the already deeply unfair information economy of getting a job.

I’ve always sent an email thank you after an interview because it shows that you really want the job. Just recently I went on an interview and did not get the position I applied for but the office manager really appreciated my follow-up, which was quite lacking in all the other applicants. Even if you do not get the job always send a thank email acknowledging you weren’t the chosen applicant but hope that who was chosen works out as you never know what will happen.

Well it was the opposite for us actually. I was interviewing someone for a government position. Although I told the person to show up early, because of security and often people get lost finding their way around the building, however the person showed up a little late (25 minutes), but they actually did somehow decent in the interview. I was on the edge , but at the end my boss and I agreed that if the person sends a thank you email then we will go ahead and offer her the position. Anyway she didn’t send the thank you email and the offered the position to someone else.

Not just because of the thank you note. As a hiring manager, that definitely would not be the determining factor. I have to know that the job candidate can perform well and had the support of the selection committee. But, a thank you note is something that will set a job candidate apart. I always send them myself, and I’ve had numerous people comment through the years that they were impressed by my thank you notes. Send one. And, for an even classier touch, invest in good personalized notecards or stationery.

Not that I know of. Offering a job to someone because they sent a thank you letter would be very shallow and unprofessionnal. It would be insulting to candidates who researched the company, prepared for the interview and gave it their all to learn that the job was offered to some candidate because of a thank you email.

Yes. I had a finalist candidate interviewing for an engineering role a few years ago. It was down to two people, and the race was tight. My candidate sent thank you notes after each round of interviews. Apparently, the other candidate did not. The hiring manager extended the offer to my candidate and, later, told me that this was the deciding factor. Sometimes, it’s that close. Don’t blow it on something that should just be a no-brainer.

For the IT roles for which I’ve been recruiting, it would be a waste of time. Managers barely had time to evaluate candidates adequately. In 99% of cases, a leading candidate would be chosen, based on skills and personality, and offer negotiation would start. In case he/she wouldn’t accept, either the interviewing process would restart or #2 on the list would be tried to be hired. In extremely rare cases of ties, they would be resolved on their own by one of the candidates accepting an offer from a different company. No one paid any attention to thank-you notes or follow-up letters.

Absolutely, it's an irrovicable requisite for me with candidates. We could have a great interview but if you don't send a follow up letter you loose serious points with me if not your overall chance of being hired. When I don't see a follow-up post interview message, it speaks to me that the individual lacks cooth, maybe lacks motivation, or simply didn't care enough about the job not to mention horrible follow up. If you did the hard part by dressing up and showing up, don't fK it up by not following up!

Yes! I interviewed for a Office Mgr/ Personal Assistant position for a design firm. After the interview, I sent a thank you note by snail mail. I was told later by the Accounting Mgr that it was that letter I mailed that got me the job. The owner was trying to decide between me and another person and chose me based on that thank you letter.

Put it this way. If you Interview with me and you DON’T send a Thank you email or note, you probably aren’t coming back for the next round. Unless your interview AND your resume absolutely blow me out of the water. It’s just proper etiquette in the job hunting field to show your appreciation. It’s also the perfect opportunity to emphasize a point or two from the interview. Also to maybe give a better answer to a question that you might have punted in the discussion. To let them know you are engaged and want to be a part of the company.

This doesn't 100% answer your question, but at the very least, I have gone through all the interviews from sending thank your's. I will say that, I personally always send out written Thank you's the same day or the day after at latest. So many people send emails now, so some really appreciate the effort (in my experience). I will send an email if they want to decide asap.

Finding a job is many times serendipitous Many time when you make contact a position just had popped up needing to be filled Your thank you note may have come up at the exact right time and you get the job People interview many people but not go back through all the applicants to fill a job that needs someone right away Thats why you have to stay in contact as much as you can A note is an innocent way of staying in contact without looking pushy

Yes. My current job as a network administrator happened that way. I had interviewed with several companies, was getting all the way to the 2nd interview and then not hired. My last interview I sent a handwritten thank you card to the manager who interviewed me a day after the interview. (This was the first time I had ever tried that.) I was hired.
Yes they have and it’s part of the overall process. On a side note, I’d recommend against offering jobs to people who ask such ill conceived, bordering on idiotic, questions like this.

You should also send either a thank you email, or send physical thank you cards. If a candidate seems unqualified, a thank you email isn’t going to get him / her the job. But I certainly view candidates who don’t send a note much less favorably than those who do - to me, it implies a lack of interest in the role and the company. I also think a note that is somewhat customized and reflects our actual conversation can make the candidate more compelling.
I can't say that I have hired because of a letter but I can say I have NOT hired because of NO letter. not thanking someone for them giving YOU time to talk about YOURSELF is straight up rude.
No. But I would have considered it, had someone followed up with a polite thank you. We ARE in the customer service industry afterall.

A thank you note certainly won’t “get” you the job - you must be qualified and stand out as the best choice for the position. But the lack of a thank-you may lose you the job. It’s a fairly basic form of courtesy - so send it!
